text: Family Member: It’s too bad they haven’t came up with something more with the bones whereas they can, you know? Doctor: Well. Family Member: Interact with- Doctor: There’s been a lot of- (Sound Door opens) Family Member: Oh, no. Doctor: Spine and ribs and shoulders. Family Member: Spine, ribs, and shoulder? (pause11sec) Doctor: Yeah. The one, the one thing we see also with, we’ve seen with the testosterone, is something called a flair. Meaning spots are there- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - but we don’t see them very well, and then we give a drug like that, they can get more intense so they show up. And I think these are spots that are, you know, been there for probably a year or two just below the radar. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It’s just a matter of, you know, we’re seeing them now. Uh, and whether the testosterone helped to see them better, that’s what we see with some other guys. So, uh, but I think certainly there’s enough there that we’ve got to keep- Family Member: Do something else? Yeah.

text: Patient: Oh, no. I saw what you said, yeah. Family Member: He went here. Doctor: Oh. You went here? Patient: Yeah. I misunderstood. Yes. Doctor: Okay. I didn’t realize, okay. Patient: Well, last time I got the bone scan in D___. Doctor: I know. Yes. Yes. Patient: B___ C___. Doctor: Yeah. Whatever. So in between, I may, I may just give you a script to hold on for a PSA. Okay? Patient: Yes. Yes. Doctor: Like six weeks or so. If the PSA creeps up a little bit, I may want that in-between lab work. Okay? But, otherwise, I, if everything looks good, and- Patient: Very good. Okay. Sounds good.

text: Patient: Oh, mind blowing. Doctor: Really? Patient: Yes. Doctor: You did like safaris and stuff? I remember you told me about it. Patient: Yeah. We did safaris and the scenery. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, uh, they’ll just tell you what to worry about, what not to worry about, what fevers we worry about, what numbers to call, uh, what you can eat, what you don’t eat sometimes. I don’t know what the class really is about. Patient: Okay. Family Member: So, S_ had, um, he was getting chemo, he had a bathroom that nobody was supposed to use. Doctor: They’ll talk to you about that and teach it in the class, but I don’t think that’s an issue. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So, what, what other questions do you have? Patient: I read the, the, the information which you gave me. I - trepeditation about the, my actual response to all of this. And, I won’t know that until we start. So. I really don’t have anything other than - I wanna get it started. It’s my fourth visit, and you’re a great guy. But, next time, I want you to stick a needle in my arm or something. Doctor: Yeah. So, yeah we, you know, my problem with this stuff is, you know, the hormone therapy does good on it’s own. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, we are adding more into it, so we can’t always tell you what the, um, adding in the chemo is gonna do. We can’t tell you what the surgery is gonna do. But, the outcome really is a number of men that don’t need therapy once we stop everything. Patient: Mm, hmm.

text: Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Right. Doctor: But, and it’s also a drug that if you take it long-term, you can get side effects from it, in terms of immune system. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: People tend to, you know, it tends to pop your appetite up, so you feel like you want to eat more. Patient: Give me the glasses. Doctor: It can also affect your skin. Some people, their skin gets very thin, and they bruise easily, particularly at the higher doses. So we, we could try the other one. I, I mean- Family Member: But you feel that would be less tiresome-? Doctor: Well, I just tell you my global experience with both drugs. Doctor: Has been it seems like both of them has a side effect, fatigue. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But my experience with using both drugs now, it seems like it’s a little bit more with the Xtandi. text: Healthcare Professional: Yes, okay. Doctor: So get in touch with ___ and/or myself. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And let me know that you’re coming actually the week after that. Like as soon as you feel you kinda know and then if we do go down the route of radiation therapy I can refer you to the radiation oncologist here to do that treatment. Patient: Okay, and now what would your role continue to be when I move to another physician? Doctor: Yes, I don’t deliver radiation therapy since I’m a medical oncologist. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So in the short term you go down that route and do the other therapy and they monitor you on that, and then once that part of it’s completed you’d come back to – Patient: Um hum. Come back to you, okay. You stay in the loop somewhere. Doctor: My hands Dr.__ is also going to be in the loop because he is the one who referred you. Patient: Yes, yes, I’ll have to; I’ll make an appointment with him. I saw him about maybe about six weeks ago and he had mentioned that they were starting up some trials in GW. I’m more comfortable where I am now, to be very honest with you. Doctor: Uh hum.

text: Family Member: What does cure mean? Doctor: Cure means that once we’re done all this therapy, the cancer is gone forever. Family Member: So, so yeah - Doctor: Which we won’t know for five, ten years. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Unfortunately you know you’re a survivor now. Patient: Right. Doctor: And it’s a diagnosis you’ll carry and you’re we don’t - not really out of the woods for five or ten years. Family Member: And then when you say not cured, if the cancer will come back would those people be considered to be in remission? Doctor: So if, so when we get his PSA undetectable and finished therapy, he’s in remission. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Even so on the hormones. Family Member: Uh hum.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay and I did mention to you that your testosterone is also going up. Patient: Right. Doctor: However, I think given the fact that you’re feeling relatively well. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Except for that slight increase in fatigue, perhaps, and given that the PSA level is still very low, and I can’t imagine that a PSA of zero point five comes high to you or your body or you know increase the risk of this prostate cancer causing you know either side effects or um you know even death because it’s still quite low. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: My approach would be as we discussed last time to wait until that PSA level goes above one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But if we don’t. That may not happen for three months; it may not happen for six months. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: If it continues at the same pace it will probably happen – have the PSA will reach one point zero in the next year. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: I know. Doctor: No, you don’t, no. Patient: I don’t need the shot? Doctor: No. Patient: Good. Okay, I’ll just let it go. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
